raw_text:
Virus poses as Christmas e-mail
 
 Security firms are warning about a Windows virus disguising itself as an electronic Christmas card.
 
 The Zafi.D virus translates the Christmas greeting on its subject line into the language of the person receiving infected e-mail. Anti-virus firms speculate that this multilingual ability is helping the malicious program spread widely online. Anti-virus firm Sophos said that 10% of the e-mail currently on the net was infected with the Zafi virus.
 
 Like many other Windows viruses, Zafi-D plunders Microsoft Outlook for e-mail addresses and then uses mail-sending software to despatch itself across the web to new victims. To be infected users must open up the attachment travelling with the message which bears the code for the malicious bug. The attachment on the e-mail poses as an electronic Christmas card but anyone opening it will simply get a crude image of two smiley faces.
 
 The virus' subject line says "Merry Christmas" and translates this into one of 15 languages depending of the final suffix of the e-mail address the infected message has been sent to. The message in the body of the e-mail reads: "Happy Holidays" and this too is translated. On infected machines the virus tries to disable anti-virus and firewall software and opens up a backdoor on the PC to hand over control to the writer of the virus. The virus is thought to have spread most widely in South America, Italy, Spain, Bulgaria and Hungary. The original Zafi virus appeared in April this year. "We have seen these hoaxes for several Christmases already, and personally I prefer traditional pen and paper cards, and we recommend this to all our clients too," said Mikko Hypponen, who heads F-Secure's anti-virus team.
llama3.2:1b: Security firms are warning about a Windows virus that disguises itself as an electronic Christmas card, translating the holiday greeting into the recipient's language.
The virus spreads through attachments containing malicious code and tries to disable anti-virus software and open up backdoors on infected machines.
The virus appears to have originated in South America, Italy, Spain, Bulgaria, and Hungary, and is thought to be one of several similar viruses.
llama3.2:3b: Windows virus disguises itself as Christmas e-mail with subject line translation in 15 languages, spreading across the web by opening malicious attachment.
gemma2:2b: A Windows virus disguised as a holiday e-card is spreading widely online.
The Zafi.D virus translates "Merry Christmas" into 15 languages, allowing it to spread globally.
It targets Microsoft Outlook and disables security software before accessing the victim's computer.
This virus is thought to have originated in April of this year and has been a recurring problem for several years.
qwen2.5:0.5b: A Windows virus disguises itself as a Christmas card in e-mails to spread quickly online.
Anti-virus companies have detected that 10% of the messages on the internet contain malicious code.
The subject line translates the message into different languages depending on the recipient, and users must open the attachment to receive the message.
The infected email bears the code for the malicious bug, posing as an electronic Christmas card but leading to a backdoor in the computer system.
The virus spreads from South America, Italy, Spain, Bulgaria, and Hungary.
qwen2.5:1.5b: A Windows virus pretending to be an electronic Christmas card has infected 10% of the internet with 5 languages available, spreading mainly in South America, Italy, Spain, Bulgaria, and Hungary.

The virus uses email addresses and mail-sending software to target victims, translating greetings into various languages before attaching a picture or message that opens on the victim's computer without causing damage but disabling security measures and allowing remote control by its author.
qwen2.5:3b: Virus Zafi.D disguises as a Christmas e-card, translating the greeting into recipient’s language to spread.
It steals email addresses from Microsoft Outlook and sends itself via infected attachments posing as a holiday card.
Users get a crude image of smiley faces; subject line and message translate based on recipient’s address suffix.
The virus disables anti-virus and firewall software, opens a backdoor for control, and is most prevalent in South America, Italy, Spain, Bulgaria, and Hungary.
Mikko Hypponen from F-Secure recommends traditional paper cards instead.
opencoder:1.5b:
Virus posing as Christmas e-mail

Security firms are warning about a Windows virus disguising itself as an electronic Christmas card.
The Zafi.D virus translates the Christmas greeting on its subject line into the language of the person receiving infected e-mail, which helps spread across online networks.
Anti-virus firm Sophos said that 10% of the e-mail currently on the net was infected with the Zafi virus, suggesting it may be a widespread threat.
The virus tries to spread using Microsoft Outlook's sophisticated attachment handling and mail-sending software.
Users must open up the attached file for the code to initiate the malicious bug.
The e-mail message appears as an electronic Christmas card but anyone viewing it will merely display two face-smiley images, which is contrary to good e-mail standards.
The virus's subject line is "Merry Christmas" and translates this into a greeting in 15 languages depending on the recipient's final suffix of the email address they have been sent from.
The message itself says "Happy Holidays" and also translates.
The virus tries to disable antivirus software on infected machines, granting them control back to the sender of the virus.
The virus is spread widely in South America, Italy, Spain, Bulgaria, and Hungary, marking it as a first-rate tool for online security purposes.
smollm:1.7b: The Zafi virus is a malicious program that disguises itself as an electronic Christmas card in order to spread it online.
It uses the language of the person receiving the infected e-mail to translate its subject line and body into different languages, making it harder for anti-virus firms to detect.
The malware also tries to disable anti-virus software and open up a backdoor on the infected machine to hand over control to the writer of the virus.
It is thought to have spread most widely in South America, Italy, Spain, Bulgaria and Hungary.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The virus named Zafi.D disguise itself as a Christmas email by translating its message into different languages.
It infects many e-mails and spreads online through Outlook addresses, requiring users to decode messages for malicious bugs.
The subject line contains "Merry Christmas," translated into 15 languages based on the sender's address.
The body of the email translates "Happy Holidays."
tinyllama:1.1b: One of the viruses known as "Zafi.D" has been spreading widely online since last year, posing as an electronic Christmas card with multi-lingual ability to deceive recipients into believing they have received a legitimate message.
A security firm warns that the malware is helping this virus spread wider.
The Zaif.D is a Windows virus that tries to disable anti-virus and firewall software, open a backdoor on infected computers and hand over control to the writer of the virus.
This multi-lingual ability may help it evade detection by security software but experts warn that this only increases its chances of spreading beyond its intended targets.
The original Zaif virus appeared in April 2018.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The text mentions a Windows virus called Zafi.D that looks like an electronic Christmas card, masquerading as the greeting in the subject line and changing the body to say "Happy Holidays."
This malicious program is spreading by infecting e-mails and making them display its message using Microsoft Outlook.
If a user opens these emails, they will receive a crude image of smiley faces.
The virus also disables anti-virus and firewall software on the infected PC, leaving it vulnerable to attack.
These attacks are spreading across several regions in recent years, including South America, Italy, Spain, Bulgaria, and Hungary.
phi:2.7b: A Windows virus disguises itself as an electronic Christmas card by translating the greeting on its subject line into the language of the recipient.
It is sending itself across the internet using mail-sending software and can be spread through attachments posing as e-mails with a crude image.
The virus aims to disable anti-virus and firewall software, open up a backdoor, and control infected machines.
It has been most prevalent in South America, Italy, Spain, Bulgaria, and Hungary, but the original Zafi virus appeared in April of this year.
Experts advise traditional pen and paper cards as an alternative.
orca-mini:3b: A virus poses as a Christmas e-mail and can be spread widely through online networks by disguising itself as an electronic greeting message.
The malicious program steals Microsoft Outlook addresses and uses mail-sending software to send itself to new victims, who must open the infected attachment in order to become infected.
The subject line of the e-mail says "Merry Christmas" and translates this into one of 15 languages depending on the final suffix of the e-mail address the infected message has been sent to.
The message in the body of the e-mail reads "Happy Holidays" and is also translated.

The virus tries to disable anti-virus and firewall software and opens a backdoor on the PC to hand over control to the writer of the virus, which has spread most widely in South America, Italy, Spain, Bulgaria, and Hungary.
hermes3:3b:
Zafi.D virus
 Christmas e-mail disguise
 Windows virus
 Spreads widely in South America, Italy, Spain, Bulgaria & Hungary
 Translates "Merry Christmas" & "Happy Holidays" into recipient's language
 Opens backdoor on infected PCs to control writer of virus
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Security firms caution about a Windows virus named Zafi.D, disguising itself as an electronic Christmas card.
The virus adapts the Christmas greeting in the subject line to the recipient's language.
Anti-virus companies speculate this multilingual ability contributes to the malicious program's widespread spread online.
Sophos reports that 10% of the e-mail currently on the internet is infected with the Zafi virus.
The malware infects recipients by exploiting Microsoft Outlook and uses mail-sending software to spread itself to new victims.
A crude image of two smiley faces is displayed instead of the malicious attachment.
The subject line's "Merry Christmas" phrase can be translated into one of 15 possible languages based on the infected message's destination e-mail address.
The body of the e-mail contains "Happy Holidays," also translated.
Infected machines attempt to disable anti-virus and firewall software, as well as opening a backdoor to hand control over to the virus writer.
The Zafi.D virus is believed to have spread most extensively in South America, Italy, Spain, Bulgaria, and Hungary.
Mikko Hypponen, head of F-Secure's anti-virus team, expressed that his company prefers traditional pen and paper cards, and recommends this to clients as well.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Security firms warn of the Zafi.D Windows virus, which disguises itself as an electronic Christmas card and spreads by translating its subject line into the recipient's language.
The virus harvests e-mail addresses from Microsoft Outlook and sends itself to new victims.
To be infected, users must open the attachment, which displays a crude image of two smiley faces.
Once active, the virus disables security software and opens a backdoor for remote control.
It has spread widely, especially in South America and parts of Europe.
Experts advise caution and recommend traditional holiday cards instead.
stablelm2:1.6b: Security firms warn of a Windows virus disguising as an electronic Christmas card called Zafi.D.
It can translate the greeting on its subject line into different languages and is spreading widely online.
The virus targets Microsoft Outlook for email addresses and uses mail sending software to infect users by opening attachments with the code for the malicious bug.
Once infected, it tries to disable anti-virus and firewall software and creates a backdoor on the PC to hand over control to the writer of the virus.
It appears most widely in South America, Italy, Spain, Bulgaria, and Hungary.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Security firms are alerting about a Windows virus named Zafi.D, which disguises itself as an electronic Christmas card with a personalized greeting in the recipient's language.
This multilingual feature is believed to aid its rapid spread online.
The virus infects 10% of emails on the internet, according to Sophos.
Upon opening the attachment, which appears as a Christmas card, users inadvertently activate the malware.
The email's subject line reads "Merry Christmas," and the body says "Happy Holidays."
Both are translated into one of 15 languages based on the recipient's email address suffix.
Once infected, Zafi-D disables antivirus and firewall software, and creates a backdoor to give control to its creator.
The virus is predominantly spread in South America, Italy, Spain, Bulgaria, and Hungary.
The original Zafi virus surfaced in April.
Mikko Hypponen, head of F-Secure's anti-virus team, prefers traditional pen-and-paper Christmas cards and advises others to do the same due to this digital threat.
